title: 106_hr1384
content: The Act is titled the "Four Corners Interpretive Center Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purposes section. The Four Corners Monument is significant as the only location in the US where 4 state boundaries meet: Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah. Boundary lines were drawn between 1868 and 1875, with a monument erected in 1899. A postal stamp will be issued in 1999 to mark the centennial. The area holds historical, cultural, and prehistoric value. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park lacks permanent facilities but attracts visitors annually. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park, located within the Navajo Nation or Ute Mountain Ute Tribe reservations, attracts around 250,000 visitors annually. The Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe have a Memorandum of Understanding for park development. The Four Corners Heritage Council was established in 1992 with state funding for planning and construction of an interpretive center. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park has potential for development, with studies showing benefits for the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. The Arizona Department of Transportation has estimated costs for an interpretive center and surrounding infrastructure. This center would offer educational opportunities for all Americans, with potential for federal assistance and expertise. Federal financial assistance and technical expertise are needed for the construction of an interpretive center at the Four Corners Monument. The purposes of this Act include recognizing the area's importance, assisting the Navajo Nation and Ute Mountain Ute Tribe in establishing the center, showcasing collaborative resource stewardship, and promoting knowledge of the region's life, art, and culture. The Act aims to promote knowledge of the culturally diverse groups in the Four Corners region, including their life, art, culture, politics, and history. The Act aims to promote knowledge of culturally diverse groups in the Four Corners region, including life, art, culture, politics, and history. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Center" as the Four Corners Interpretive Center, "Four Corners Heritage Council" as a nonprofit coalition, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, "Recipient" as the states of Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, or Utah, and "Four Corners monument." The Four Corners Monument is where the boundaries of Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah meet. The Four Corners Monument Tribal Park includes lands within its legally defined boundary. The Four Corners Monument Interpretive Center is located at the Four Corners Monument where Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, and Utah meet. The Secretary is authorized to establish the Four Corners Interpretive Center within the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park. Land for the Center will be designated by the Navajo Nation or the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe in consultation with the Four Corners Heritage Council and in accordance with specific agreements. The Four Corners Interpretive Center will be established with the consent of the Navajo Nation and the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. It will feature exhibits on the region's heritage, public education programs, preservation efforts, and visitor amenities. The Four Corners Interpretive Center will offer visitor amenities such as restrooms and public telephones. SEC. 5. CONSTRUCTION GRANT. The Secretary can award a Federal grant for up to 50% of the Center's construction cost to the recipient. The recipient must ensure that the non-Federal share of costs is covered by non-Federal sources, including contributions from States, private sources, the Navajo Nation, and the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe. States can use private funds to meet the requirements. States can use private funds to meet the requirements of receiving a grant under this act. The State of Arizona may apply $45,000 for planning and $250,000 for construction towards the Arizona share. Recipients must submit a proposal meeting all applicable laws, requirements under a Memorandum of Understanding, and provide necessary information and assurances to the Secretary. Recipients must also enter into a Memorandum of Understanding with the Secretary to receive the grant. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the Secretary must include a timetable for construction, competitive awarding of contracts, compliance with building codes, operations and maintenance plans, educational programming, and exhibit design details. The Memorandum of Understanding with the Secretary must include a timetable for construction, competitive awarding of contracts, compliance with building codes, operations and maintenance plans, educational programming, exhibit design details, presentations in accordance with professional museum standards, an agreement with the Navajo Nation and the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe for site selection and public access, and a financing plan developed jointly by the tribes outlining long-term management of the Center. The Memorandum of Understanding with the Secretary must include a timetable for construction, competitive awarding of contracts, compliance with building codes, operations and maintenance plans, educational programming, exhibit design details, presentations in accordance with professional museum standards, an agreement with the Navajo Nation and the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe for site selection and public access, and a financing plan developed jointly by the tribes outlining long-term management of the Center. Additionally, it should outline other income generation strategies, achieving financial self-sufficiency within 5 years, and appropriate vendor standards and business activities at the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park. The Secretary is authorized to award a grant for the design of facilities at the Four Corners Monument Tribal Park. The Four Corners Heritage Council may provide recommendations on grant proposals. Authorization of appropriations is also granted. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the maintenance and operation of the center, program development, or staffing in accordance with the requirements of the Act. Funds can be carried over if unexpended and reserved by the Secretary until a proposal meeting the Act's requirements is submitted. Additionally, donations are addressed in Section 8. The Secretary is allowed to accept donations of funds, property, or services for the planning, construction, and operation of the Center. The Act does not affect any rights or claims of the Navajo Nation or the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe based on existing laws.
